bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, June 23, 1879

div1.p: Reed teases Emilie Lawrence Reed. He offers news from the base. He is glad to hear that she is feeling better.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, June 23, 1879
div1.opener:
Fort Apache, A.T.
June 23rd 1879.
Tell papa's boy
“digger, digger, dig-
-ger”- Mama
“Boodigs”!
My pretty little picture:
div1.p:
The mail brought
Papa a real long, sweet letter from Mama,
yesterday afternoon, dated June 4th; and old papa
is up, this morning, real early, answering it.
He is ever so much obliged to his darling little
wifie for writing so punctually, for every mail
brings papa a letter & makes him feel so happy.
So if you don't get your letters promptly, my
pretty darling is coming back to Apache? What
lovey? Coming all the way back to old Apache?
No, No! You can't do that, my pretty picture.
Somebody said that if she once got east, she'd
never come back! Who was that little darling?
Is she beginning to get tired this soon? My, this will
never do- Although there is a nice, fat ox team
at Otero, that can make about 3 miles a day, ready
to bring you to Apache whenever you start.
Never mind, lovey dear, mantee won't joke
any more- He knows you are just as happy
as you can be east & don't wan't to come
back to old, lovely Apache; and that you are
just as pretty & sweet & precious & apple pie
& good as you can be & are going to enjoy
your darling self & be a good dear little
wifie, till mantee comes, however distant in
the future that may be- What does Miss Tib-
-bie think of that darling boy of Papa's & Mama's?
It must have seemed strange to you, my dar-
-ling wife, to have seen your own little son,
romping about in the old home- The old home
where mantee y used to come up the brick
walk as straight as a ram-rod, & with his
plug hat so slick that it was sure death to
any fly that dared attempt to perch thereon:
The old home where mantee used to ring the
door-bell & ask, if “Miss Lawrence was in”,
the old home where “chiquita sofa” mama &
papa used to sit on & do so much courting,
where papa offered his hand to darling mama,
& where mama accepted it, & then wanted papa
to kiss her, & papa, like a great idiot, didn't
have sense enough to do it! A few years
gone by, & then to return & see your own little
“Laurie” running about & making things merry
with his happy prattle & laughter! How papa
should liked to have seen him! One thing is
very sure, he is an ornament into whatever
house he may go; & there never was but one
finer child in the old home, & that was my
own precious wifie, who would wear shoes
with the toes all out! Do you know, lovey
dear, that you haven't so much as told me
what any one of your family think of the
boy, except Col. Harrell-? not a word about
your mother's opinion- or Sister Ellen's or
Dr John's or Mr Charles' or any one of the homefolks.
& this after my darling wife had promised to
write Papa just what homefolks said. The
only conclusion I can draw is that they haven't
yet seen the boy, or if the have, they said noth-
ing at all! Never mind Mama, dear, Papa won't
send you any sweet kisses, if you forget to
tell him anything about his darling boy - Papa
does so hope that Mr Grimes has had good
success with his photographs, & he expects
certainly to get one next Sunday- But you
said nothing about your own, my darling
wifie- Now, remember that your old “hubby”
is just as anxious to get his pretty, precious
wife's picture as he is to have that of his dar-
-ling boy - & if you haven't already had one
taken, you must be sure to do so, when you get
to Harrisonburg- I know my darling wifie
is looking forward to a happy time, this summer,
at Grand-ma Reed's- Couldn't you get your
mother to consent to go?- It would have been
such a splended visit & such a pleasant
one for her- Wouldn't she come up to H'burg,
if you & Miss Annie shared the expense? If
so, don't fail to make the offer- How papa
wishes that he couldn have been ordered out
this summer & could be with his darlings in the
valley- What times we would have had, & what
stories we would have told of Arizona ad-
-venture! But although Papa can't be there,
he knows that his pretty wife & her Sister will
have a very happy time- Grow fat, my pretty
little darling, & “Kick” all & everybody you please!
Husband will be responsible for anything you
do. If Sister Annie will consent, he wants you
to take a flying trip to Rawley Springs, to
stay a week or two, or just as long as you
could stay away from our darling Laurie-
Papa knows it would do his little dar-
ling good & help her to pass away the time-
Go where you please, my lovey, so you
don't hurt yourself & if anybody bothers
you, just double up your little “fistigs” &
give them a good “whack”, & charge it to mantee!
I must here stop awhile, as guard-mount is
over & it is time for breakfast- Our mess is,
just at present, rather small- Mr Gatewood &
Dr McPherson away on a scout & Lt. Mills
gone to Thomas on a short tour- We are thus
reduced to Lt. Stanton, Cap't. Mc Gowan, & Lt. Reed,
11 o'clock A.M. Well I didn't think it would be
so late before I got another chance to con-
-tinue my letter- I've had to go to the Tailor's,
lance an inflamed gum, interview a pris-
-oner as to whether he will plead “guilty” or
not, and sold my chairs since breakfast time.
At 1 P.M. lunch comes & at 1.30 a Garrison
Court, of which I am Recorder, so that I
must make the best of the next two hours
that I possibly can. The chairs, my sweet
wifie, I sold to a Mormon butter-dealer- He
gave me three dollars a piece for the four chairs
& four dollars for the Rocker- or $16.00 for the lot;
I was glad enough to get rid of them at that
price- I had tried to sell them to various
parties, but without success, & had begun
to think that I had an “Elephant” on my
hands, when lo! The Stranger appeared & took
them. I offered them at $20.00, but he would
only give $16.00- I could have fallen on
his neck & wept. Henceforth the cut of his
noble countenance will ever be before me.
May his “olive-branches” luxuriate & climb
all over him; which will doubtless be the
case, as he has many wifes- The little rifle
was purchased by the Nuncio of his Holiness
for the sum of $25.00 cash, paid down-and I
think I can sell the gun that Lt. Ray gave
me for $20.00, certainly for $15.00- I have just
put it in good order, & have two Agents can-
-vassing the garrison with the view of disposing
of it- to wit: Ned. Altman, alias the “Nuncio”, and
John Alberti, alias the “Russian bear”. If I only
get $15.00 it will give me $56.00 for the 2 guns &
chairs, which completely meets my satisfaction.
What does the sweetest woman in the world
think about it? I have taken the old carpet
back & bottom out of the large folding chair,
which weyou had your worked strip on in the parlor,
my darling Emilie, & sent it over to the Carpenter
shop to be re-glued & an extension put on it,
so as to make it a real comfortable reclin-
-ing chair - when it is done, I shall try to beg
enough leather of Wm, the conqueror, to put
a good bottom & back to it- If can't get it, I
will put it away & when we get east, we
can have an a nice bottom of rep or carpet
put in it, & then it will be a good, strong chair.
That & our 2 dining-room chairs, & the larger one
of the two small folding chairs, & the leather, folding
chair that I bought of Lt. Gatewood, making
five in all, I shall pack up & bring with me.
They are all real, sound, serviceable chairs
& there is no use selling them out here at
a sacrifice & then having to buy them again
when we start house-keeping east, Don't you
thingk I am right, my precious wife? Concerning
your gold necklace, I haven't received the bill
from Mr Lucas yet. When I was in Santa Fe,
May 3rd, on my return, I saw Mr Lucas' clerk
Mr Pegram, & they said that it would be done
by June 1st, but added that they had some
work in the shop which wished to get rid
of, before beginning your's & Mr. Mill's necklace-
I presume they may have been out of gold
dust, just at the time, & this would of course delay
it- I think it likely that you will get it by last
of June or 1st of July- You will remember, lovey,
that I told Mr Lucas that I would not have
the money till the end of June & this may be
is why he is not in a great hurry- He told me that
he would do just as handsome a job & fit as he
could- Have patience, Mantee's pretty little Em-
ilie, wifie, it will be alright, & then you will
have several real pretty presents from
Mantee, won't you my love? Husband wishes
that they were a thousand times more valuable,
& then they would not be what his pretty,
precious little bride deserves! Love her heart!
I have real sad news to tell you about poor
little Undina! You remember that I wrote
you, my darling, that she was going to have
puppies- Well, I was mistaken - she was only
growing fat & stout- It was a case of Miss
“miss fire” on the part of the hairless brute-
She has been very lively & full of fun & on
(page 9-)
last Saturday morning,(To-day is Monday) on my re-
turn from Sick - Call, I never saw her more
playful- She was, as usual tearing around
& trying to bite my legs all the way from the
Hospital- When I got home I sat down on
the porch to- read, & Undina laid down by my
chair & apparently went to sleep- About
an hour after, when I started to breakfast,
I noticed that she was not very lively & would
eat nothing at the mess- During the day she be-
came very much cramped about her belly &
I gave her a dose of castor oil, which opera-
-ted freely- At night time she could hardly stand
on her hind legs, & yesterday morning, when I
got up I found the poor little thing complete-
ly paralyzed, from the middle of her body back-
wards- She couldn't move her hind legs or wag
her tail- She is now in the same condition-
Can raise up on her fore paws & drag her-
self only about six inches at a time- She lies
quietly in my room on the bear's skin & looks
up at me so pitifully & pleadingly that it
makes me real sad- Isn't it too bad, my pre-
cious wifie? I am certain that she ate some-
-thing that poisoned her, but I am in great
hopes that she will recover- She takes milk very
well- Says “tell mittie I'se so tick”. Sends
her best love & a kiss to little Mottie & Mittie.
You say, my darling, that I must keep you
posted on Army news- Well, I don't know
much, except that there have been a great
many Retirements & Promotions during the
month of June- A new Colonel,(Col. Carr.)
Lieut. Col.(I forget his name) & a new major,
(David A. Perry.) come to the 6th cavalry- Major
Perry will, we think, come to Apache as Comman-
-ding Officer. I told you, I believe, that, Major colonel
Compton had been promoted to be Lieutenant
Colonel of the 5th cavalry, an excellent Regiment
He & Mrs. C. will leave about two weeks, from
this time, & probably be stationed at Fort Mc
Kinney, in Wyoming Territory- I tell you
what, my little lovie, our new Captain, McGow-
-an, is just bucking right up to the fair
widow- Adam has had his kno nose knocked
“clean out of joint” & has taken a “back seat”,
“We cannot, always tell”, but Mrs. Compton,
the Col. & I think that the Captain will propose,
& we are not sure that the buxom lass
will give him the mitten! That's just how
the matter stands- “May the brave only win
the fair”! It is only 12.20 P.M. but I must stop,
my precious wifie, in order to see the witnesses
who will testify before the Court this afternoon.
Tuesday afternoon, 24th- Well, husband must conclude
his “ittle etter”, & after filling it with a heap of
love & kisses for papa's little darlings, must then
seal it up & send it on its way- “Hubby” has
been busy all the morning, making a beautiful
fishing pole with which to “yerk” (or “yank,”) the
festive trout from his pensive lair - & to-morrow,
perhaps, he will try a “spin up the creek-” Do you
remember, lovey, dear, how the bugs served the
gardens, last year? If anything, they have been
worse this year - All of my seed were peeping
forth very nicely & had raised their tiny heads
about one inch high, when along came the
bugs & ate them all down - nothing whatever
left. Fortunately, I had not planted all my
seeds- I have sown again & things once
more look a little promising. As the rainy
season will soon set in, (indeed we had
a slight shower night before last,) I am
hoping that my garden will be a success,
although of necessity it needs must be late-
Little wifie, dear, I “pec” will have plenty of
nice vegetables in the valley & good things to put
in her “ittle tummy.” Papa is so glad to have Ma-
-ma write that her health has much improved-
May you get all of the miserable Arizona mala-
-ria out of your darling little “carcass;” and may
your precious cheeks grow pink & rosy like those
of a peach; may your sweet little legs grow
as plump as a spring chicken's, & your darling
little “tummy” become as round as a butter ball!
And when you have reached the stage just de-
-scribed, your old mantee is coming east to
take a good -- look at you! Ha! Ha! love its
pretty heart, mantee thinks its the dearest,
sweetest wife & mother in all this world, and he
wouldn't take 20 yoke of oxen for his lovely
precious darling- She is all in all & over all
in this world! He loves her more than he loves
his life, & he knows his love increases everyday!
He could eat her up bone & muscle! First Comes
mother, darling mother, then papa's precious little Son,
& these two are his own & only jewels! Brighter than
diamonds to his eye, & sweeter than the honey in the Comb,
to his heart! Love & kisses, love & kisses, love & kisses for Mama & son!
Love to all - write soon & often, my pretty darling, to your fond, loving & devoted
husband.
